[SYNTAX]: Incongruous phrases ("The battery read full capacity", "A digital display counted down silently") disrupting flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unrelated inserts ("battery", "digital display") disrupt narrative continuity;
[TRANSITION]: Mild disjointedness between paragraphs (e.g., shift from Italy to self-control discussion).

[ANACHRONISM]: "The voice-activated controls blinked to life" is historically inconsistent with 18th-century context.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Reynolds' personal traits to historical details of the Royal Academy without clear bridging. - [CONTEXTUAL ASSUMPTION] Assumes reader familiarity with figures like Dr. Johnson and historical art movements without elaboration.

[SPELLING]: Anachronistic terms ("5G signal", "surveillance drone", "smart paper") disrupt historical context.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally convoluted sentence structures (e.g., Northcote’s introduction).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between topics (e.g., Foundling Hospital to Reynolds’ 1769 achievements).
[STRUCTURE]: Fragmented narrative with loosely connected ideas (artistic critiques, social life, legacy).

[LEXICON]: Anachronistic terms ("e-ink wallpaper", "phone") disrupt historical context.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences (e.g., "He sought for the colour of Rubens...")
[TRANSITION]: Mild abruptness between paragraphs (e.g., shift from artistic technique to "Artists tell us...")

[STRUCTURE]: Slight thematic disjointedness (e.g., critique of female portraits feels somewhat isolated)
[TRANSITION]: Minor lack of explicit connections between ideas (e.g., art vs. literature paragraph)
